Merge pull request #95 from brion/refactor-iframe

Fixes several issues:
* no more clickthrough issues with scrolling & the floating search bar
* content area is now sized correctly on Android 4
* no longer tries to open random things in browsers on Android 4

There may be some changes to styles in general, but it seems to be mostly fixed up.


With the divs it's also easier to integrate libraries like iscroll to manage scroll & zoom behavior; this works well on ICS with a fast phone but is too slow on Android 2.x on a Nexus One, so not yet integrating that full. Scrolling is still done on the whole document, with a position:fixed searchbar.

Nightly build show the same version number every night which is not very
helpful when testing a build. Jenkins publish environnement variables we
can use to override that version to something like:

 jenkins-2012-01-04_23-14-42_#32

Jenkins env variables are listed in its documentation:
  https://integration.mediawiki.org/ci/env-vars.html

aapt an not override versionName (nor versionCode) if it is set in the
AndroidManifest.xml. So I had to move it to project.properties.
If BUILD_ID and BUILD_NUMBER are set the version.name property is set,
and the value in project.properties will be ignored.

First steps at getting app to run on apps without Google proprietary APIs (such as Amazon Kindle Fire tablet)

* switched <uses-library> manifest entry for Google Maps to indicate that it is not required -- this lets the app install and run on devices without the proprietary APIs.
* cleaner loading of the NearMeActivity class in the NearMePlugin, so we can catch a class lookup failure and return an error instead of crashing.

The map view still loads on my Nexus One (without the actual maps, but I think that's because it needs a registered key to "really" work).
On Kindle Fire, the app installs and runs and the map view triggers the error dialog and lets you back to where you were before.

Partial hack for bug 31835 -- article area waaaay too small on Android 3 & 4

The iframe on Android 2 expands to its full size, and we let the entire document scroll around on a fixed-expanded iframe.
But on Android 3 and 4, it defaults to a couple hundred px high and doesn't auto size to fit.

Switching things around to lay it out at a fixed size within the window would be preferable but as soon as you scroll *the iframe*, tapping in the iframe breaks -- tapping on links etc hits where things are without scroll, instead of where they are now.

For now, at load time I'm just stretching the iframe's height to match the internal document height. This works well enough until you expand some sections, at which point the document gets taller and things end up scrolling within the iframe and exploding again. Sigh.

But, at least things are visible. ;)

title: Stub localization for PhoneGap-based Android app
message:
Stub localization for PhoneGap-based Android app Pulls in jQuery and a stub of MediaWiki's JavaScript front-end APIs covering Map and Message classes. Code can call mw.msg() or mw.message() to fetch localized messages, passing a key and parameters etc. mw.msg() returns a string, while mw.message() returns a Message object, offering a subset of MediaWiki's PHP Message class Use of the object form is recommended because it makes it much more explicit whether you're getting things for plaintext or for HTML (where you usually want to make sure escapes of special characters get applied). Say for this message: {'error-loading-page': 'Error loading page "$1"'} You might need plain text for some purposes like an alert dialog: alert(mw.message('error-loading-page').params(pageTitle).plain()); Or you might need to put it into HTML output and make sure it's escaped: out += '
  • ' + mw.message('error-loading-page').params(pageTitle).escaped() + '
    • '; This is VERY important to prevent code injection when working with an HTML-based interface! Stub localization messages are in messages/messages-en.js; there's not yet infrastructure to load up other languages but this should be pretty straightforward. Descriptions of messages go into the messages-qqq.js file; this is very important to help translators figure out the context of what they're translating. A good place to explain parameter usage etc! We may change from the .js files to something more standardy if that's easier to integrate with TranslateWiki.
